1.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Romaniuk (Building Distinctive Brand Assets), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute
1.brief: Mental availability is defined by Romaniuk and Sharp as 'the probability that a buyer will notice, recognize and/or think of a brand in buying situations' dependent on 'the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand.' Mental availability ensures your brand is recalled in relevant buying moments, not just recognized. As the Ehrenberg-Bass Institute research shows, brands grow primarily by increasing their mental availability and physical availability. Brand growth comes from acquiring new and light buyers, and mental availability is the mechanism by which brands become easier to think of and therefore more likely to be chosen. The key is linking the brand to as many category entry points as possible. Our brain is a lazy organ that has evolved over millions of years to make good choices with as little energy consumption as possible. We operate automatically and use our attention sparingly. In purchasing environments, this leads to 99.99% of all stimuli being filtered out. This makes it difficult for brands to influence choice unless they have strong mental availability.
keyQuotes: Mental availability is the probability that a buyer will notice, recognize and/or think of a brand in buying situations, dependent on the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand. - Romaniuk & Sharp, Journal of Advertising Research, 2016

Mental availability ensures your brand is recalled in relevant buying moments. You can be everywhere, but are you everywhere for the right reasons? The goal isn't just to be known, it's to be the instinctive choice at the moment of need. - People the Brand

Our brain is a lazy organ that has evolved over millions of years to make good choices with as little energy consumption as possible. In purchasing environments, this leads to 99.99% of all stimuli being filtered out. - Unravel Neuromarketing Research
keyFindings: Mental availability is established as the primary driver of brand growth according to Ehrenberg-Bass Institute research
Brands with higher mental availability enjoy higher market share because they are more likely to come to mind in buying situations
Awareness helps people know your brand, but mental availability makes them choose your brand when it matters
Brand growth comes primarily from acquiring new and light buyers, not from increasing loyalty among heavy buyers

2.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge)
2.brief: Daniel Kahneman describes two systems of thinking: System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control. System 2 allocates attention to the effortful mental activities that demand it, including complex computations. The intuitive System 1 is more influential than your experience tells you, and it is the secret author of many of the choices and judgments you make. Thaler and Sunstein use the terms Automatic System and Reflective System. The Automatic System is associated with the oldest parts of the brain, the parts we share with lizards. Using this framework helps understand how we can be so ingenious at some tasks and so clueless at others. System 1 does X is a shortcut for X occurs automatically. And System 2 is mobilized to do Y is a shortcut for arousal increases, pupils dilate, attention is focused. The two systems do not really exist in the brain or anywhere else, but they are useful fictions for understanding cognition.
keyQuotes: System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control. System 2 allocates attention to the effortful mental activities that demand it, including complex computations. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.23
The intuitive System 1 is more influential than your experience tells you, and it is the secret author of many of the choices and judgments you make. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.17

We call them the Automatic System and the Reflective System. The Automatic System is associated with the oldest parts of the brain, the parts we share with lizards. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.45-46
keyFindings: System 1 is the secret author of many choices and judgments, operating automatically with no sense of voluntary control
The Automatic System (System 1) is associated with the oldest parts of the brain shared with reptiles
System 2 is mobilized when arousal increases, pupils dilate, and attention is focused on effortful mental activities
The two systems do not really exist in the brain but serve as useful shortcuts for understanding how cognition works

3.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Shotton (The Choice Factory), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing)
3.brief: Robert Cialdini describes social proof as one of the key principles of influence. As he writes, 'We view a behavior as more correct in a given situation to the degree that we see others performing it.' Social proof is most powerful when we are uncertain and when the people we observe are similar to us. Richard Shotton documents that personalizing social proof messages makes them more potent: 'Most guests reuse their towels' produced 44% towel reuse, but 'Most hotel guests in this room reuse their towels' achieved 49% reuse. Nancy Harhut explains that social proof isn't always about following the crowd: sometimes people think that others actually know more than they do. What someone's family and close friends were doing was more likely to affect their behavior than whether or not they themselves believed social distancing was important. It overrode even their personal convictions on the topic. A study found that 98% of online shoppers consider authentic customer reviews the most important factor in their purchase decisions.
keyQuotes: We view a behavior as more correct in a given situation to the degree that we see others performing it. - Cialdini, Influence, p.134

Personalising amplifies social proof. 'Most guests reuse their towels' = 44% towel reuse vs 'Most hotel guests in this room reuse their towels' = 49% reuse. - Shotton, The Choice Factory, citing Cialdini's hotel towel study

What someone's family and close friends were doing was more likely to affect their behavior than whether or not they themselves believed social distancing was important. It overrode even their personal convictions. - Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.81
keyFindings: Social proof is most powerful under conditions of uncertainty and when observed from similar others
Personalizing social proof messages to be more specific significantly increases their effectiveness
Social proof from close relationships can override personal convictions on a topic
98% of online shoppers consider authentic customer reviews the most important factor in purchase decisions

4.sources: Kahneman & Tversky (Prospect Theory), Cialdini (Influence), Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing
4.brief: Kahneman and Tversky's Prospect Theory demonstrates that outcomes which are obtained with certainty are overweighted relative to uncertain outcomes. The value function for gains is concave, while losses are felt more acutely. People will be reluctant to trade what they own, except at a high price, a phenomenon known as the endowment effect, which is driven by loss aversion. Cialdini notes that under conditions of risk and uncertainty, people are intensely motivated to make choices designed to avoid losing something of value, to a much greater extent than choices designed to obtain that thing. In Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, the analysis shows that the way choices are presented (framed) and the information processing of receivers affect the way in which decisions are made. If the framing is manipulated, people can be pushed towards particular alternatives. Loss aversion, mental accounting, and risk tolerance all affect the evaluation of prospects.
keyQuotes: Under conditions of risk and uncertainty, people are intensely motivated to make choices designed to avoid losing something of value, to a much greater extent than choices designed to obtain that thing. - Cialdini, Influence, p.225

The way choices are presented (framed) and the information processing of receivers affect the way in which decisions are made. If the framing is manipulated, people can be pushed towards particular alternatives. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.364
People will be reluctant to trade what they own, except at a high price. Loss aversion is behind the endowment effect. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.343
keyFindings: Losses loom larger than gains: people feel roughly twice as much pain from losing something as pleasure from gaining the same thing
The endowment effect causes people to demand much more to give up an object than they would pay to acquire it
Framing marketing messages around preventing loss rather than achieving gain can significantly increase persuasive impact
Loss aversion, mental accounting, and risk tolerance together affect how prospects are evaluated

5.topic: The Long and Short of It
5.sources: Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It, Effectiveness in Context), IPA Databank
5.brief: Les Binet and Peter Field's meta-analysis of the IPA effectiveness Databank, covering 996 campaigns, 700 brands, and 83 categories over 30 years, reveals that short and long term effects are different. Short term effects are vital but long-term brand building is the main driver of growth and profit. Their research establishes the 60:40 rule: the optimal split is approximately 60% of budget allocated to brand building and 40% to sales activation, delivering maximum efficiency and effectiveness. Brand building takes over as the primary driver of growth from sales activation after six months. Brands that set their share of voice above their share of market tend to grow, while those that set SOV below SOM tend to shrink. The annualised ESOV efficiency has been increasing, meaning SOV is becoming more important. Brand building reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. The movement towards real-time campaign management and its inevitable focus on short-term results means marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice.
keyQuotes: The 60:40 split delivers maximum efficiency. Brand building takes over as the primary driver of growth from sales activation after six months. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It, IPA

To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice, and there is an urgent need for long-term metrics to reassert their importance. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It

Brand building is ultimately more effective, because the effects last longer and so accumulate over time. Brand building also reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. - LinkedIn B2B Marketing Report
keyFindings: The optimal brand/activation budget split is approximately 60:40, delivering maximum efficiency and effectiveness
Brand building takes over as the primary driver of growth from sales activation after six months
SOV is becoming more important over time, with annualised ESOV efficiency increasing
Short-term metrics damage long-term profitability when used as primary performance measures

6.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Ariely (Predictably Irrational), Dooley (Brainfluence)
6.brief: Kahneman demonstrates that the anchoring effect is not a laboratory curiosity; it can be just as strong in the real world. In an experiment, real-estate agents assessed the value of a house based on different asking prices. Half saw a substantially higher asking price than the listed price. The agents were significantly influenced by the asking price, yet insisted they were not. Similar or even larger anchoring effects have been observed in numerous studies of estimates and willingness to pay. As Kahneman notes, arbitrary rationing is an effective marketing ploy: supermarket shoppers in Sioux City, Iowa, bought significantly more Campbell's soup when presented with an anchor number. Dooley explains how Ariely discovered that MIT students bid 3x more when primed with a random higher number. If we decide to buy a big-screen television, we may spot one we like for $1,000. We may not buy that item, but according to Ariely that now becomes an anchor price against which other deals are measured. Anchoring effects are easily observed in online trading, where the same item is often offered at different buy now prices.
keyQuotes: The anchoring effect is not a laboratory curiosity; it can be just as strong in the real world. Real-estate agents were significantly influenced by the asking price, yet insisted they were not. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.123

Arbitrary rationing is an effective marketing ploy. Supermarket shoppers encountered a sales promotion for Campbell's soup and bought significantly more when presented with an anchor number. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.125

Dan Ariely discovered how MIT students bid 3x more when primed with a random higher number. Even irrelevant information can anchor your consumers. - Dooley, Brainfluence; Ariely, Predictably Irrational
keyFindings: Anchoring effects are pervasive in real-world settings including real estate, retail, and online trading
Even professionals who insist they are not influenced by anchors show significant anchoring effects
Arbitrary and irrelevant numbers can serve as effective anchors that influence purchasing decisions
Anchoring makes us far more suggestible than most of us would want to be

7.sources: Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It, Effectiveness in Context), Nielsen, LinkedIn B2B Report
7.brief: The share-of-voice model shows that brands that set their share of voice (SOV) above their share of market (SOM) tend to grow, and those that set SOV below SOM tend to shrink. The rate at which a brand grows or shrinks tends to be proportional to its extra share of voice (ESOV), defined as the difference between SOV and SOM. According to Nielsen research, every 10 points of excess SOV can drive approximately 0.5% of extra market share growth. The share of voice rule has been known for 50 years and holds true today, despite all the enormous changes in the media landscape. From Effectiveness in Context, the bigger the brand, the higher the base rate, meaning big brands can get away with setting share of voice slightly below market share and still maintain equilibrium. But small brands are more dependent on advertising to maintain market share. They need to keep SOV much more in line with SOM if they are to survive. Big brands use advertising to maintain their market share and to boost margins, which is highly profitable.
keyQuotes: Brands that set their share of voice above their share of market tend to grow, and those that set SOV below SOM tend to shrink. The rate of growth is proportional to ESOV. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
Every 10 points of excess SOV can drive approximately 0.5% of extra market share growth. - Nielsen, Budgeting for the Upturn
Small brands are more dependent on advertising to maintain market share. They need to keep SOV much more in line with SOM if they are to survive. - Binet & Field, Effectiveness in Context, p.73
keyFindings: The SOV/SOM relationship has held true for 50 years despite massive changes in media
ESOV (excess share of voice) is the primary driver of brand share growth
Big brands enjoy economies of scale and can maintain equilibrium with SOV slightly below SOM
Small brands must maintain SOV in line with SOM or risk market share decline

8.brief: Robert Cialdini establishes reciprocity as a fundamental principle of influence. As he explains, by virtue of the reciprocity rule, we are obligated to the future repayment of favors, gifts, invitations, and the like. So typical is it for indebtedness to accompany the receipt of such things that a term like 'much obliged' has become a synonym for 'thank you.' The rule was established to promote the development of reciprocal relationships between individuals so that one person could initiate such a relationship without the fear of loss. An uninvited first favor must have the ability to create an obligation. The American Disabled Veterans organization found that its simple mail appeal for donations produces a response rate of about 18 percent. But when the mailing also includes an unsolicited gift (gummed, individualized address labels), the success rate nearly doubles to 35 percent. Shotton notes that the door-in-the-face technique taps into reciprocity: when someone makes a concession by reducing their request, we feel obligated to reciprocate with a concession of our own.
keyQuotes: By virtue of the reciprocity rule, we are obligated to the future repayment of favors, gifts, invitations, and the like. So typical is it for indebtedness to accompany the receipt of such things that a term like 'much obliged' has become a synonym for 'thank you.' - Cialdini, Influence, p.24

The American Disabled Veterans organization's simple mail appeal produces about 18% response rate. But when the mailing includes an unsolicited gift, the success rate nearly doubles to 35 percent. - Cialdini, Influence, p.52

The door-in-the-face technique taps into reciprocity. When someone makes a concession by reducing their request, we feel obligated to reciprocate. In the control condition, 50% turned up. This figure rose to 85% when the door-in-the-face technique was harnessed. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.45
keyFindings: Reciprocity is a universal rule present in all cultures that obligates future repayment of favors
Unsolicited gifts nearly double response rates in direct mail campaigns (18% to 35%)
Even uninvited first favors create a powerful sense of obligation in the recipient
The door-in-the-face technique leverages reciprocity by making the target feel the requester has conceded

9.sources: Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing)
9.brief: Choice architecture is the practice of influencing choice by organizing the context in which people make decisions. Thaler and Sunstein describe how good choice architecture combines getting rid of bad options and introducing novel ones, while ensuring choices must be designed so as to make the customer journey as frictionless as possible. Status quo bias is easily exploited, and changing the default can be an effective nudge. Harhut emphasizes that when employing choice architecture, marketers should never force their customers' hands. Customers should always be able to make a different choice than the one you want them to. Research has shown that people's decisions are impacted by the way their options are presented. Removing friction and simplifying options can help people make the choice you hope they do. Your customers will have a strong preference for the status quo, for the way things are. It might be due to familiarity, loss aversion, time and effort already invested, or habit. Defaults are often perceived to be hints that they are the recommended option.
keyQuotes: Choice architecture in domains from human resource departments to social security to health care must be designed so as to make the customer journey as frictionless as possible. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.113

When employing choice architecture, marketers should never force their customers' hands. Customers should always be able to make a different choice than the one you want them to. - Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.180
Defaults are often perceived to be hints that they are the recommended option. Changing the default can be an effective nudge. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.23
keyFindings: People's decisions are significantly impacted by the way options are presented to them
Status quo bias means customers prefer the way things are, driven by familiarity, loss aversion, and habit
Removing friction and simplifying options nudges people toward desired choices
Good choice architecture preserves freedom while guiding toward better outcomes

10.sources: Romaniuk (Building Distinctive Brand Assets), Creativity in Distinctive Brand Assets (Velykyte, 2023), Unravel Neuromarketing Research
10.brief: Distinctive brand assets are the non-brand-name elements that identify a brand: colors, logos, mascots, sounds, taglines, and visual styles. Romaniuk's framework measures brand assets on two dimensions: fame (how widely known the asset is) and uniqueness (how exclusively it is associated with one brand). Color is one of the most powerful and recognizable elements of a brand's visual identity. Creative branding involves developing a unique and compelling brand personality that resonates with consumers, expressed through distinctive brand assets. Legal recognition protects a brand asset's unique identity and makes it possible for it to exist as its own entity. Some of the most famous examples include the Nike Swoosh, the Aflac Duck, and Mastercard's Priceless advertising style, all able to represent the brand without needing the brand name. Research shows logos and mascots typically grow quickly in fame and uniqueness, while other assets develop more slowly. The Distinctive Asset Grid provides a systematic way to measure and manage these assets over time.
keyQuotes: Color is one of the most powerful and recognizable elements of a brand's visual identity. - Creativity in Distinctive Brand Assets, Velykyte 2023

Brand creativity involves developing a unique and compelling brand personality that resonates with consumers, expressed through a variety of distinctive brand assets. - Lane Keller, 1996, cited in Velykyte 2023

Some of the most famous examples include the Nike Swoosh, the Aflac Duck and Mastercard's Priceless advertising style. All of these are able to represent the brand name without needing the brand name to be articulated. - Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, Report 52
keyFindings: Distinctive brand assets enable brand identification without requiring the brand name
Assets are measured on two dimensions: fame (how widely known) and uniqueness (how exclusively associated)
Logos and mascots typically grow quickly in fame and uniqueness compared to other asset types
Legal protection of brand assets enables them to exist as transferable entities independent of original goods

11.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing)
11.brief: Cialdini identifies scarcity as a powerful weapon of influence. The scarcity principle trades on our weakness for shortcuts: because we know that things that are difficult to possess are typically better than those that are easy to get, we can often use availability as a shortcut for quality. Harhut breaks scarcity into two sides: urgency and exclusivity. Urgency, expressed through limited quantities and limited times, motivates people to take action. Marketers can employ urgency using deadlines, countdown clocks, and restricted quantities. In a dramatic example, Cialdini describes a study where beef buyers who were told about future scarcity bought significantly more. Those who also learned the scarcity information was exclusive (the scarcity double whammy) purchased even more. The restriction of information made it both more desirable and more persuasive. As Cialdini notes, the finding was quite straightforward: the value of information was seen to grow if it was scarce. Not only was the commodity itself seen as more valuable, but the exclusive information about it was valued even more.
keyQuotes: The scarcity principle trades on our weakness for shortcuts. Because we know that things that are difficult to possess are typically better than those that are easy to get, we can often use availability as a shortcut for quality. - Cialdini, Influence, p.194
Things that are scarce are perceived to be more valuable and desirable. The scarcity principle has two sides: urgency and exclusivity. - Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.62

Customers who were told about future scarcity bought significantly more. Those who also learned the scarcity information was exclusive purchased even more. The scarcity double whammy. - Cialdini, Influence, p.203
keyFindings: Scarcity operates through two mechanisms: urgency (limited time/quantity) and exclusivity
Exclusive information about scarcity is even more persuasive than the scarcity itself
Marketers can employ urgency through deadlines, countdown clocks, and restricted quantities
The scarcity principle leverages our cognitive shortcut that difficult-to-obtain things are typically better

12.sources: Zajonc (via Dooley, Brainfluence), Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow)
12.brief: Psychologist Robert Zajonc demonstrated the mere exposure effect by showing non-Chinese-speaking subjects a series of Chinese ideographs. One group received five exposures, the other just one. In all cases, exposures lasted only five milliseconds or less, too fast for conscious recognition. Yet the symbols previously seen were consistently rated more positively. The familiarity had created a positive connotation. In a similar experiment, members of the group with repeated exposure reported being in better moods. Kahneman connects this to cognitive ease: repetition induces cognitive ease, and things that are cognitively easy feel more familiar and more likable. Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols (like KAR or LUNMOO) outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers like PXG or RDO. A study in Switzerland found that investors believe stocks with fluent names like Emmi and Swissfirst will earn higher returns than those with clunky labels like Geberit and Ypsomed. The mere exposure effect works with characters, musical tones, and faces alike.
keyQuotes: Robert Zajonc demonstrated the mere exposure effect by showing subjects Chinese ideographs for only five milliseconds or less, too fast for conscious recognition. The symbols previously seen were consistently rated more positively. - Dooley, Brainfluence, p.92
Repetition induces cognitive ease. Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.68
Members of the group with repeated exposure to certain characters reported being in better moods than those without. This mere exposure effect works in ads as well. - Nudge Podcast transcript
keyFindings: Mere exposure works even at subliminal levels (five milliseconds), below conscious awareness
Familiarity created through repeated exposure generates positive emotional associations
Processing fluency (ease of recognition) translates directly into preference and liking
The effect extends to financial markets: stocks with pronounceable names outperform tongue-twisting ones

13.topic: Q1 Synthesis: The Science of Being Chosen
13.sources: Multiple Q1 sources: Sharp, Kahneman, Cialdini, Binet & Field, Romaniuk
13.brief: The Q1 research reveals a coherent framework for understanding how brands get chosen. Mental availability (Sharp, Romaniuk) ensures brands come to mind in buying situations. System 1 processing (Kahneman) means most purchase decisions are automatic and intuitive, not deliberate. Social proof (Cialdini) shows people look to others when uncertain. Loss aversion means framing around what could be lost is more powerful than what could be gained. The 60:40 rule (Binet & Field) establishes the optimal balance between brand building and activation. Anchoring demonstrates that even arbitrary numbers influence purchasing decisions. The SOV/SOM relationship shows that share of voice drives market share growth. Reciprocity, choice architecture, distinctive brand assets, scarcity, and mere exposure all operate as System 1 shortcuts that shape brand selection. Together, these principles show that brands don't win by rational persuasion but by building mental availability through consistent, broad-reach advertising that creates positive associations and leverages behavioral biases.
keyQuotes: System 1 is the secret author of many of the choices and judgments you make. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow
Brands grow primarily by increasing their mental availability and physical availability. - Sharp, How Brands Grow
To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
keyFindings: Brand choice is primarily driven by System 1 shortcuts, not rational deliberation
Mental availability is the central mechanism through which brands become chosen
Behavioral biases including social proof, scarcity, anchoring, and reciprocity all operate as System 1 heuristics
Long-term brand building through broad reach is more effective than short-term rational persuasion

14.sources: Cialdini (Pre-Suasion), Presuasion: The Hidden Forces That Influence Negotiations
14.brief: Cialdini's Pre-Suasion explores how communicators can pre-suade by focusing recipients initially on concepts that are aligned, associatively, with the information yet to be delivered. The mechanism involves an underappreciated characteristic of mental activity: its elements don't just fire when ready, they fire when connected. Priming an individual before a particular task can assert a certain hidden force upon that individual's selection or decision-making processes. If individuals were truly rational in the traditional sense, then priming should have no effect. Privileged moments are windows in time when individuals are particularly receptive to a message. The communicator who can fasten an audience's focus onto the favorable elements of an argument raises the likelihood of persuasion. Besides drawing attention to a particular stimulus, there is considerable benefit to holding it there. Naturally occurring commanders of attention include the sexual, the threatening, and the different. Women perform better on math, science, and leadership tasks if assigned to rooms with cues (photos, for example) of women known to have mastered the tasks.
keyQuotes: A communicator pre-suades by focusing recipients initially on concepts that are aligned, associatively, with the information yet to be delivered. The mechanism involves an underappreciated characteristic of mental activity: its elements don't just fire when ready, they fire when connected. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion

Priming an individual before a particular task can assert a certain hidden force upon that individual's decision-making processes. If individuals were truly rational, then priming should have no effect. - Presuasion: The Hidden Forces That Influence Negotiations, p.27
The communicator who can fasten an audience's focus onto the favorable elements of an argument raises the likelihood of persuasion. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion
keyFindings: What happens before a message is delivered is as important as the message itself
Priming works because mental elements fire when connected to related concepts, not just when ready
Privileged moments are windows when individuals are particularly receptive to a communicator's message
Environmental cues (photos, room setup) significantly influence subsequent behavior and performance

15.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
15.brief: Framing effects demonstrate that the way information is presented fundamentally changes how people respond to it. Thaler and Sunstein provide a powerful example: telling homeowners they lose $350 per year from insufficient insulation (loss frame) is more effective than telling them they could save $350 per year (gain frame). Framing effects are exacerbated by the human tendency to occasionally be mindless, passive decision makers. Few of us bother to check whether reframing the decisions we face would produce a different answer. Shotton connects framing to Kahneman's WYSIATI concept: we make decisions based on the known knowns, considering only the information before us and ignoring potentially relevant factors we cannot perceive at that moment. As Kahneman writes, WYSIATI means that we use the information we have as if it is the only information. We do not consider what we might not know. This is why how you frame a choice matters enormously for marketing communications.
keyQuotes: Information campaign framed in terms of loss might be more effective. If the government wants to encourage energy conservation, the loss frame looks like a stronger nudge. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.44
WYSIATI means that we use the information we have as if it is the only information. We do not consider what we might not know. - Kahneman, via Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.124

Framing effects are exacerbated by the Human tendency occasionally to be somewhat mindless, passive decision makers. Few of us bother to check to make sure reframing the decisions we face would produce a different answer. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.44
keyFindings: Loss-framed messages are consistently more motivating than equivalent gain-framed messages
People rarely check whether reframing a decision would produce a different answer
WYSIATI (What You See Is All There Is) means people decide based only on available information
The same objective information produces different decisions depending on how it is presented

16.sources: Orlando Wood (Lemon, Advertising and the Divided Brain), System1 Group
16.brief: Orlando Wood examines what kind of creative work is needed by exploring the different modes of attention and how they relate to the left and right hemispheres of the brain. Drawing on psychiatrist and neuroscience researcher Iain McGilchrist, he explains that the right brain presents broad-beam attention while the left brain focuses narrow-beam attention. Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands. System1 analysis confirms that left-brained features are far more common in today's advertising than right-brained elements. The rise of the left-brained style of advertising has occurred in the last 10-15 years. Video campaigns ordered on skew towards number of right brain features show higher average number of very large business effects. Orlando identifies features that appeal to either the left or right brain, demonstrating that right-brain campaigns drive very large business effects through emotional engagement, characters, stories, and distinctive settings.
keyQuotes: Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands. - Wood, Advertising and the Divided Brain
Left-brained features are far more common in today's advertising than right-brained elements. This confirms the rise of the left-brained style in the last 10-15 years. - System1 Group analysis
Video campaigns ordered on skew towards number of right brain features show higher average number of very large business effects. - Wood, Advertising and the Divided Brain
keyFindings: Right-brain advertising (emotional, characters, stories) drives significantly more very large business effects
Modern advertising has shifted heavily toward left-brain features in the last 10-15 years
Broad-beam attention captured through emotional response is essential for building strong brands
The attention crisis in advertising is partly caused by the dominance of rational, left-brain approaches

17.sources: Romaniuk (Category Entry Points in a B2B World), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, LinkedIn B2B Institute
17.brief: When entering a buying situation, a category buyer first draws on existing memories to identify potential brands for purchase. These memory-generated consideration sets are the foundation of Category Entry Points (CEPs). Professor Jenni Romaniuk introduces CEPs as the cues that buyers use when thinking about a category. The CEP roadmap involves four steps to building a winning marketing strategy. Brands need to build wider, fresher memory networks of CEPs linked to the brand. When building CEPs in marketing communications, there are three dimensions to consider: more decision makers, more CEPs per decision maker, and stronger links between CEPs and the brand. For B2B, the CEP framework extends to consider the professional as a person with their own desires and ambitions, such as making a splash to help get promoted. The long-term message strategy needs to build brand links to different CEPs rather than just continuously focusing on only one CEP. As the B2B Institute states, 'The most important search engine is still the one in your mind.'
keyQuotes: When entering a buying situation, a category buyer first draws on existing memories to identify potential brands for purchase. These memory-generated consideration sets are Category Entry Points. - Romaniuk, Category Entry Points in a B2B World, p.10
The most important search engine is still the one in your mind. - B2B Institute, Foreword to Category Entry Points in a B2B World
The long-term message strategy needs to build brand links to different CEPs, rather than just continuously focusing on only one CEP. - Romaniuk, Category Entry Points in a B2B World, p.16
keyFindings: CEPs are the memory-generated cues buyers use when entering a buying situation
Brands need to build links to multiple CEPs rather than focusing on just one
Three dimensions of CEP building: more decision makers, more CEPs per person, stronger brand links
CEPs apply equally to B2B and B2C, though B2B must also consider professional ambitions

18.brief: Google's research identifies the messy middle of purchase behavior as a cycle of exploration and evaluation. Against a backdrop of exposure encompassing brands, products, and more, purchase triggers prompt consumers to enter a cycle of exploration and evaluation, gathering information and then narrowing it down. If the first cycle doesn't yield a definite choice, they loop back, repeating as many times as necessary. The exploration and evaluation loop is the defining characteristic of the messy middle, and the seemingly infinite construct is key. Consumers explore their options and expand their knowledge and consideration sets, then either sequentially or simultaneously evaluate the options and narrow down their choices. Behavioral science principles can be applied at several points within the messy middle. Brands should show up at key moments of exploration and evaluation to win or protect market share. Intelligent application of behavioral science can help create a compelling proposition that appeals to shoppers at an instinctive level. Pre-existing brand affinity and price are undoubted drivers, but purchase outcomes can also be strongly influenced by messages and tactics that competing brands bring into play.
keyQuotes: Purchase triggers prompt consumers to enter a cycle of exploration and evaluation, gathering information and then narrowing it down. If the first cycle doesn't yield a definite choice, they loop back, repeating as many times as necessary. - Google, Decoding Decisions, p.96
The exploration and evaluation loop is the defining characteristic of the messy middle. - Google, Decoding Decisions, p.23
Show up at key moments of exploration and evaluation to win or protect market share. - Google, Decoding Decisions, p.97
keyFindings: The consumer journey is not linear but a looping cycle of exploration and evaluation
Behavioral science principles can be applied at several points within the messy middle
Pre-existing brand affinity provides significant advantage in the exploration-evaluation loop
Purchase outcomes are strongly influenced by the messages and tactics brands bring into the messy middle

19.brief: Neuromarketing applies neuroscience insights to marketing. Dooley explains that understanding how customers' brains work leads to better products and better marketing. People experience a neurochemical reward when they acquire new information, which is why novelty works in marketing. Implicit measures reveal different attitudes than explicit surveys. Zaltman's research on implicit associations shows that people displayed much more positive attitudes toward particular brands and toward alcohol consumption generally when measured implicitly compared to focus groups and surveys. Response latency measures returned a different assessment of the size and composition of target markets than traditional methods. As one consensus map or thought is activated, it can stimulate another thought within that same map or even in a related map. Whenever a new thought is activated, it primes yet additional thoughts. This spreading activation explains how brand associations work at a neurological level and why marketers must understand implicit rather than just explicit consumer responses.
keyQuotes: People experience a neurochemical reward when they acquire new information. That information doesn't have to be War and Peace or learning the proof for a mathematical theorem. - Dooley, Brainfluence, p.227

People displayed much more positive attitudes toward particular brands and toward alcohol consumption generally when measured implicitly compared to focus groups and surveys. - Zaltman, How Customers Think, p.140

As one construct or thought within a consensus map is activated, it can stimulate another thought within that same map or even in a related map. Whenever a new thought is activated, it primes yet additional thoughts. - Zaltman, How Customers Think, p.249
keyFindings: Implicit measures reveal fundamentally different consumer attitudes than explicit surveys and focus groups
The brain rewards novelty with neurochemical responses, explaining why new information captures attention
Brand associations work through spreading activation: one thought primes related thoughts automatically
Traditional research methods may systematically underestimate the strength of brand associations

20.sources: Cialdini (Influence), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
20.brief: Cialdini identifies commitment and consistency as a powerful principle of influence. As Harhut explains, citing Cialdini: 'Once we have made up our minds about an issue, stubborn consistency allows us a very appealing luxury: We really don't have to think hard about the issue anymore.' Maintaining consistency is easy, requiring no subsequent thought time or further analysis. The general idea in sales is to pave the way for full-line distribution by starting with a small order. When a person has signed an order for your merchandise, even though the profit is so small it hardly compensates for the time and effort, he is no longer a prospect, he is a customer. Shotton describes the foot-in-the-door technique: by actually creating a really small initial action, you make the first genuine step on the journey seem as easy as possible. The contrasting door-in-the-face technique is more lateral, making the genuine ask seem small by comparison. Both are two-step approaches trying to achieve the same thing.
keyQuotes: Once we have made up our minds about an issue, stubborn consistency allows us a very appealing luxury: We really don't have to think hard about the issue anymore. - Cialdini, cited in Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.124

When a person has signed an order for your merchandise, even though the profit is so small it hardly compensates for the time and effort of making the call, he is no longer a prospect, he is a customer. - American Salesman, cited in Cialdini, Influence

The foot-in-the-door technique creates a really small initial action. The door-in-the-face technique makes the genuine ask seem small by comparison. Both are two-step approaches. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.47
keyFindings: Consistency is a cognitive shortcut that eliminates the need for further analysis after a decision
Small initial commitments dramatically increase the likelihood of larger subsequent actions
Both foot-in-the-door and door-in-the-face techniques leverage the consistency principle
Starting with a small order converts a prospect into a customer, triggering consistency effects

21.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Alter & Oppenheimer
21.brief: Cognitive ease, or fluency, is the experience of how easy something is to process mentally. Kahneman explains that the technical term for cognitive ease is fluency, citing Alter and Oppenheimer's work 'Uniting the Tribes of Fluency to Form a Metacognitive Nation.' When people are instructed to frown while doing a task, they actually try harder and experience greater cognitive strain. Frowning normally accompanies cognitive strain and the effect is symmetric. Things that are easy to process feel more familiar, more true, and more likable. A sentence that was literally true but hard to process may be doubted, while a rhyming sentence feels more truthful. Words that rhyme are judged as more accurate than equivalent non-rhyming statements. Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers, and investors believe stocks with fluent names will earn higher returns. For marketers, this means that messages, brand names, and creative content that are easy to process will be perceived as more trustworthy and appealing.
keyQuotes: The technical term for cognitive ease is fluency. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.463, citing Alter & Oppenheimer

Stocks with pronounceable trading symbols like KAR or LUNMOO outperform those with tongue-twisting tickers like PXG or RDO. Investors believe stocks with fluent names will earn higher returns. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.68

When people are instructed to frown while doing a task, they actually try harder and experience greater cognitive strain. The effect is symmetric: frowning accompanies cognitive strain. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.132
keyFindings: Processing fluency directly influences perceived truthfulness, familiarity, and liking
Rhyming statements are judged as more accurate than non-rhyming equivalents
Brand names and stock tickers that are easy to pronounce outperform difficult ones
Physical states (frowning vs. smiling) interact with cognitive ease to influence judgments

22.sources: Wood (Advertising and the Divided Brain), Binet & Field (The Long and the Short of It), LinkedIn B2B Report
22.brief: Orlando Wood's analysis shows that right-brain campaigns (emotional, character-driven, story-based) drive significantly more very large business effects than left-brain campaigns (rational, information-heavy). Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands. Binet and Field's IPA Databank analysis confirms that emotional campaigns are more effective for long-term brand building: brand building is ultimately more effective because the effects last longer and so accumulate over time. Brand building also reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. As a result, brand building is the main driver of long-term growth and profit. The LinkedIn B2B Report extends these findings to business markets, establishing that harnessing the power of emotion is one of five key principles for effective B2B advertising. Emotional engagement is not just a B2C phenomenon. A high degree of emotional engagement was common across all successful campaigns, with the most effective ads invoking emotion in a credible way.
keyQuotes: Broad-reach advertising that elicits an emotional response and captures broad-beam attention is how you build and maintain strong brands. Right-brain campaigns drive very large business effects. - Wood, Advertising and the Divided Brain
Brand building is ultimately more effective, because the effects last longer and accumulate over time. Brand building also reduces price sensitivity and increases margins. - LinkedIn B2B Report
Things like emotional engagement were common across all successful campaigns, with the most effective ads invoking emotion in a credible way. - System1 analysis
keyFindings: Right-brain emotional advertising drives significantly more very large business effects
Emotional effects accumulate over time, making them the main driver of long-term growth
Left-brain rational advertising has become dominant in the last 10-15 years despite being less effective
Emotional advertising effectiveness applies to B2B markets, not just consumer brands

23.brief: Cialdini identifies authority as a key principle of influence. Our obedience to authority frequently takes place in a click, whirr fashion, with little or no conscious deliberation. Information from a recognized authority can provide us a valuable shortcut for deciding how to act in a situation. Conforming to the dictates of authority figures has always had genuine practical advantages for us. Being viewed as either in authority or an authority leads to increased compliance, but the first type (merely being in charge) often generates resistance and resentment. The second type (being viewed as highly informed) avoids this problem, as people are usually willing to follow expert guidance. A communicator who does the work of collecting and then pointing to support from multiple experts will be more successful than one who settles for claiming the support of just one. In one experiment, college students' brains showed that decision-making parts showed less activity when receiving advice from a renowned economist, as students offloaded the burden of the decision process to the expert.
keyQuotes: Our obedience to authority frequently takes place in a click, whirr fashion, with little or no conscious deliberation. Information from a recognized authority can provide us a valuable shortcut for deciding how to act. - Cialdini, Influence, p.174

A communicator who does the work of collecting and then pointing to support from multiple experts will be more successful than one who settles for claiming the support of just one. - Cialdini, Influence

When students received advice from a renowned economist, the decision-making parts of their brains showed less activity as they offloaded the burden of the decision process to the expert. - Google, Decoding Decisions, p.50
keyFindings: Authority influence operates automatically, often without conscious deliberation
Being viewed as an expert (authority on a topic) is more effective than merely being in charge
Citing multiple experts is more persuasive than citing just one authority figure
Brain scans show people literally offload decision-making effort when an expert provides guidance

24.sources: Kahneman (Thinking, Fast and Slow), Shotton (The Illusion of Choice)
24.brief: Kahneman's research reveals the peak-end rule: the global retrospective rating of an experience is well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment (the peak) and at the end. Duration neglect means the length of an experience has surprisingly little effect on our memory of it. It does not make sense to evaluate an entire life by its last moments, or to give no weight to duration in deciding which life is more desirable, yet this is what our remembering self does. The remembering self is a construction of System 2, but the distinctive features of how it evaluates episodes and lives are characteristics of our memory. Shotton draws on Milan Kundera's observation that 'memory does not make films, it makes photographs,' meaning we remember snapshots of events rather than their full duration. Our brains don't have the capacity to store every moment. Instead, we capture a fraction of what happens. This has profound implications for customer experience design: invest disproportionately in the peak moment and the ending.
keyQuotes: The global retrospective rating was well predicted by the average of the level of pain reported at the worst moment and at the end. Duration neglect: the length of an experience has surprisingly little effect on memory. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.371
It does not make sense to evaluate an entire life by its last moments, or to give no weight to duration, yet this is what our remembering self does. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.400
Memory does not make films, it makes photographs. We remember snapshots of events, rather than their full duration. - Milan Kundera, cited in Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.178
keyFindings: Experiences are evaluated based on their peak intensity and ending, not their overall duration
Duration neglect means the length of an experience barely affects how it is remembered
The remembering self is a System 2 construction but evaluates using memory characteristics
Customer experience design should invest disproportionately in peak moments and endings

25.sources: Shotton (The Illusion of Choice), Duhigg (The Power of Habit via Thinking in Bets)
25.brief: Habits make quick-fire decision making possible. Without habits we'd struggle to deal with the complexity of life. Habits form through the habit loop of cue, routine, and reward. As Duhigg explains, the golden rule of habit change says we don't have to give up the reward; instead we can substitute what makes us feel good. Shotton's research shows that if you want to encourage behaviour change, it's not enough just to boost motivation. Often, increased desire doesn't translate into behaviour change. You also need to create a cue that will prompt the desired action. Implementation intentions, effectively triggers to remind people to act, dramatically increase follow-through: in one study, 91% exercised at least once a week when given a trigger, compared to those with motivation alone. Nationwide's 2019 campaign introduced 'Pay Day = Save Day' as a cue, reporting an eight-percentage point rise in recognition of saving importance and finishing the year with net savings balance five times forecast. Rather than create a cue from thin air, it's often better to attach the behaviour you're trying to encourage to an existing behaviour.
keyQuotes: If you want to encourage behaviour change, it's not enough just to boost motivation. Often, increased desire doesn't translate into behaviour change. You also need to create a cue. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.24

91% exercised at least once a week when given an implementation intention (a trigger), compared to those with motivation alone. The trigger gave the nebulous desire something to coalesce around. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.24

Nationwide introduced 'Pay Day = Save Day' as a cue. Their post-campaign tracking reported an eight-percentage point rise in the recognition of the importance of monthly saving. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.25
keyFindings: Motivation alone is insufficient for behavior change; a cue or trigger is essential
Implementation intentions (specific triggers) increase follow-through from baseline to 91%
Attaching new behaviors to existing routines (Pay Day = Save Day) is more effective than creating new cues
The habit loop of cue, routine, and reward can be modified by substituting the routine while keeping the reward

26.sources: Multiple Q2 sources: Cialdini, Kahneman, Wood, Romaniuk, Google Research
26.brief: Q2 reveals how behavioral principles can be deliberately applied to engineer consumer choice. Pre-suasion (Cialdini) shows that what happens before a message determines its impact. Framing effects (Kahneman) demonstrate that presentation changes decisions. The attention economy (Wood) reveals that emotional, right-brain advertising drives more business effects. Category entry points (Romaniuk) provide a systematic framework for building brand-relevant memories. The messy middle (Google) maps the exploration-evaluation loop where behavioral science principles can be applied. Neuromarketing fundamentals show that implicit associations matter more than explicit attitudes. Commitment and consistency create escalating engagement. Fluency makes messages feel true. Emotional advertising outperforms rational approaches. Authority provides shortcuts for decisions. The peak-end rule shows where to invest in experiences. And habit formation demonstrates that cues, not motivation, drive behavior change. Together these tools give marketers a systematic toolkit for engineering choice at every stage of the decision journey.
keyQuotes: A communicator pre-suades by focusing recipients initially on concepts that are aligned with the information yet to be delivered. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion
The exploration and evaluation loop is the defining characteristic of the messy middle. - Google, Decoding Decisions
If you want to encourage behaviour change, it's not enough just to boost motivation. You also need to create a cue. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice
keyFindings: Choice can be systematically engineered using behavioral science principles at every touchpoint
The decision journey is a looping cycle, not a linear funnel, with multiple intervention points
Emotional and implicit approaches consistently outperform rational and explicit methods
Cues, framing, and pre-suasion are more powerful than information and motivation alone

27.sources: Binet & Field (Effectiveness in Context, The Long and the Short of It), IPA Databank
27.brief: Binet and Field's analysis of the IPA Databank demonstrates that brand building is the primary driver of long-term growth and profitability. Their meta-analysis covers 996 case studies, 700 brands, 83 categories over 30 years. Effectiveness is measured in terms of effects, not prizes. Annualised ESOV efficiency relates share growth per annum to ESOV as the primary measure of efficiency. The practical implication is that if sales success is measured over a period of less than 6 months, then the metric will favour short-term communications and marketing tactics; if over longer than 6 months, then the metric will favour long-term communications and marketing. There is a growing tendency to use very short-term online metrics as primary performance measures. So the major threat in practice is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This threat will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management. Brand price elasticity should be tracked: the lower the better. And strength of promotional response should be monitored: big responses are a sign of a weak brand.
keyQuotes: If sales success is measured over less than 6 months, the metric will favour short-term tactics; if over longer than 6 months, it will favour long-term brand building. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It

The major threat in practice is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This threat will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
Brand price elasticity should be tracked: the lower the better. And strength of promotional response: big responses are a sign of a weak brand. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
keyFindings: Brand building effects only become visible when measured over periods longer than 6 months
Short-term online metrics as primary performance measures actively damage long-term brand health
Low price elasticity and weak promotional response are signs of strong brand equity
996 IPA case studies confirm brand building is the primary driver of long-term growth

28.brief: Measuring mental availability requires tracking brand links to category entry points. Romaniuk and Sharp define mental availability metrics based on the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand. The key is measuring how many CEPs a brand is linked to, and how strong those links are. This requires tracking the brand's presence in consumers' memories across different buying situations. Unlike traditional brand tracking which focuses on unaided and aided awareness, mental availability measurement captures whether a brand comes to mind in specific purchase contexts. Measuring advertising's effect on mental availability will begin to provide expected benchmarks for marketers and aid development of strategies to build a brand's mental availability under conditions specific to the category. As mental availability is a competitive process, the advertising activity of competitors will also have an impact on memory, so comparing brands in the same category provides important extension. The Distinctive Asset Grid measures brand asset fame and uniqueness, providing a systematic framework for tracking asset performance.
keyQuotes: Mental availability is the probability that a buyer will notice, recognize and/or think of a brand in buying situations, dependent on the quality and quantity of memory structures related to the brand. - Romaniuk & Sharp, Journal of Advertising Research

Mental availability is a competitive process and the advertising activity of competitors will also have an impact on memory. Comparing brands in the same category provides important extension. - WARC Research
The Distinctive Asset Grid measures brand asset fame and uniqueness. - Romaniuk, How Brands Grow Part 2
keyFindings: Mental availability metrics should measure brand links to category entry points, not just awareness
Brand memory is competitive: competitor advertising directly impacts your mental availability
The Distinctive Asset Grid provides systematic measurement of brand asset fame and uniqueness
Expected benchmarks for mental availability will vary by category-specific conditions

29.sources: Phua, Hartnett, Beal, Trinh & Kennedy (Journal of Advertising Research, 2023), Ephron
29.brief: Research published in the Journal of Advertising Research examines what happens when brands stop advertising for a year or longer. Using market share as the measure (where prior research used sales), losses were quantified as declining by 10 percent after one year, 20 percent after two years, and 28 percent after three years relative to the last advertised year, on average. Brand size and market share trajectory before stopping advertising affect the rate of market share loss. Such quantification facilitates financial forecasting and portfolio decision making concerning advertising cessations. Despite an appreciation of the risks, it is still common for brands to have extended periods when they do not advertise. Brands stop advertising for various reasons including pressure of inflating earnings to avoid buyouts, competition for budget across brand portfolios, or other business requirements. Ephron advocated that advertising needs continuity, because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. The research adds to the evidence that continuity over the long-term benefits brand performance.
keyQuotes: Market share losses were quantified as declining by 10 percent after one year, 20 percent after two years, and 28 percent after three years relative to the last advertised year, on average. - Phua et al., Journal of Advertising Research, 2023
Advertising needs continuity, because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. - Ephron, 1995

Despite an appreciation of the risks, it is still common for brands to have extended periods when they do not advertise. Brands stop for various reasons including pressure of inflating earnings to avoid buyouts. - Phua et al., JAR 2023
keyFindings: Brands that stop advertising lose 10% market share after one year, 20% after two years, 28% after three years
Brand size and pre-cessation trajectory affect the rate of decline when advertising stops
Advertising continuity is as important as being in-stock, according to the shelf-space model
Despite known risks, brands commonly stop advertising due to budget pressures and portfolio competition

30.sources: Aggarwal et al. (GEO: Generative Engine Optimization, Princeton University/IIT Delhi)
30.brief: Generative Engine Optimization is the first general optimization framework for website owners to optimize their websites for generative engines. Generative engines, in contrast to traditional search engines, remove the need to navigate to websites by directly providing a precise and comprehensive response, potentially reducing organic traffic to websites and impacting their visibility. GEO can improve the visibility of websites by up to 40% on a wide range of queries. The research proposes visibility metrics specifically designed for generative engines. Key optimization methods include Statistics Addition (adding relevant statistics), Quotation Addition (incorporating credible quotes), and Cite Sources (including citations from reliable sources). These methods achieved 30-40% relative improvement on Position-Adjusted Word Count metrics. SEO methods such as Keyword Stuffing perform poorly in generative engines. Lower-ranked websites benefit disproportionately from GEO optimization. The framework enables content creators to flexibly optimize their content for improved visibility in AI-generated search responses.
keyQuotes: Generative Engine Optimization can improve the visibility of websites by up to 40% on a wide range of queries, domains, and real-world generative engines. - Aggarwal et al., GEO Paper
SEO methods such as Keyword Stuffing perform poorly in generative engines. Statistics Addition, Quotation Addition, and Cite Sources achieved 30-40% relative improvement. - Aggarwal et al., GEO Paper
Generative engines remove the need to navigate to websites by directly providing a precise and comprehensive response, potentially reducing organic traffic. - Aggarwal et al., GEO Paper
keyFindings: GEO can improve website visibility in AI search results by up to 40%
Adding statistics, credible quotes, and citations are the most effective GEO methods
Traditional SEO tactics like keyword stuffing are ineffective for generative engines
Lower-ranked websites benefit disproportionately from GEO optimization techniques

31.brief: Les Binet introduces Share of Search as a new metric: the ratio of searches for a brand to searches for all brands in the category. Share of searches correlates with market share across multiple categories tested. This metric leverages the world's biggest database of human intentions (search data). The IPA group's research, led by Binet and joined by organizations including Google, LinkedIn, Unilever, Kantar, Mediacom, and Zenith, validates that media investment effects can be tracked through Share of Search. MyTelescope was invited to join the IPA group, contributing both data and advanced analytics. However, the approach has limitations: you need to be careful about brands with common words in their names (like Nutmeg, which could pick up people looking for the spice). Similarly, if a major brand has multiple offerings or too large a footprint, it could confuse the analysis. Share of Search is particularly powerful as a leading indicator of market share changes, giving marketers early warning signals about competitive dynamics.
keyQuotes: Share of searches = searches for brand x / searches for all brands in category. Share of searches correlates with market share in all three categories tested. - Les Binet, adam&eveDDB
The world's biggest database of human intentions. - Les Binet, describing search data

You need to be careful about brands with common words. You could track share of search for Nutmeg (the investment company) without also picking up people looking to buy the spice. - Beyond Share of Search
keyFindings: Share of Search correlates with market share across multiple categories
Search data represents the world's largest database of human intentions and brand interest
The metric serves as a leading indicator of market share changes
Brand name ambiguity and multi-product brands require careful methodology

32.sources: Lumen Research, WARC, Follett (The True Cost of Advertising Attention)
32.brief: Mike Follett's cross-media attention research combines attention data from TVision and Lumen to show how much visual engagement ads in different media generate and whether this extra attention is reflected in the price advertisers pay. The research reveals not only what consumers could see (what was viewable), but also what they did in fact look at (what they viewed) and, crucially, how long they looked at the ad for. Combining these measures, including the percentage of ads that could be seen, the percentage actually viewed, and the average eyes-on dwell time, allows estimation of attentive seconds per impression. This is critical because viewable does not mean it will be viewed. Dwell time dramatically affects recall: compared to the low dwell-time group, those who had longer exposure to ads were six times more likely to recall the ad, four times more likely to remember details, and fourteen times more likely to correctly remember the brand. The distinction between viewability and actual attention is fundamental for media planning.
keyQuotes: Combining attention data reveals not only what consumers could see (viewable), but also what they did in fact look at (viewed), and crucially, how long they looked at the ad for. - Follett, WARC

Compared to the low dwell-time group, those who had longer exposure were six times more likely to recall the ad, four times more likely to remember details, and fourteen times more likely to correctly remember the brand. - The Choice Factory, Shotton
Viewable does not mean it will be viewed. This may help restrain the desire to overload pages with too many ads. - WARC Research
keyFindings: Viewability and actual attention are fundamentally different metrics that should not be conflated
Three seconds of attention produces 6x recall, 4x detail memory, and 14x brand attribution
Attentive seconds per impression is a more meaningful metric than viewability alone
Cross-media attention data reveals significant differences in attention quality across channels

33.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Ehrenberg-Bass Institute, DJ 50 Years on
33.brief: The Law of Double Jeopardy, tested extensively over fifty years, shows that smaller brands suffer twice: they have fewer buyers AND those buyers are slightly less loyal. As Sharp demonstrates with shampoo data, smaller brands suffer from only slightly lower loyalty. Brands grow primarily by increasing their market penetration. The law has been extensively tested over thirty-five years or more and provides a key to how brands grow. When Double Jeopardy constrains choice behaviour, brand share growth depends on substantially increasing the size of the customer base rather than managing customer loyalty. Jim Nyce, previously Insights Director at Kraft, describes this as 'swimming downstream.' Try as one might, if you are successful in gaining sales it's unlikely you'll break the double jeopardy law. And the IPA Effectiveness Awards results remind us that it is a much better strategy to go with the law than against it. Double jeopardy applies across categories from shampoo to ready-mix concrete, from radio stations to political parties.
keyQuotes: When Double Jeopardy constrains choice behaviour, brand share growth depends on substantially increasing the size of the customer base rather more than on managing customer loyalty. - DJ 50 Years on, p.3

Try as one might, if you are successful in gaining sales it's unlikely you'll break the double jeopardy law. It is a much better strategy to go with the law than against it. Swimming downstream. - Sharp, How Brands Grow, p.38
Smaller US shampoo brands suffer from only slightly lower loyalty. Brands grow primarily by increasing their market penetration. - Sharp, How Brands Grow, p.33
keyFindings: Smaller brands suffer twice: fewer buyers AND slightly less loyalty per buyer
Brand growth comes from increasing penetration (more buyers), not loyalty (more purchases per buyer)
Double Jeopardy has been replicated across 50+ years in categories from FMCG to politics
Fighting double jeopardy (focusing on loyalty over penetration) is swimming upstream against the law

34.sources: Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, Ad Spending: Maintaining Market Share
34.brief: Advertising elasticity is the ratio of the proportional increase in sales to the proportional increase in advertising. The response to advertising typically shows diminishing marginal returns: each additional exposure produces less effect than the last. When this occurs, the most cost-effective number of exposures (effective frequency) is one per person and it is best to use a continuous schedule that spreads advertising across the target population as widely as possible. Advertising elasticity is high for new brands but lower for established ones. Many long-established brands have built a useful track record of experience with varying levels of advertising pressure, and in many cases, econometric studies have produced a specific advertising elasticity. The advertising elasticity of most brands is low, which means competitors need not fear an opportunistic advertising increase too much. Even if a brand goes it alone and reduces advertising, sales may not suffer markedly in the short term, though long-term effects will accumulate.
keyQuotes: Each additional exposure produces less effect than the last. When this occurs, the most cost-effective number of exposures is one per person and it is best to use a continuous schedule spread as widely as possible. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.574
Advertising elasticity is high for new brands. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.595
The advertising elasticity of most brands is low, which promises a very limited sales uplift in response to competitive advertising increases. - Ad Spending: Maintaining Market Share
keyFindings: Advertising response follows diminishing returns: each additional exposure produces less effect
The most cost-effective frequency is one exposure per person with continuous scheduling
New brands have higher advertising elasticity than established brands
Most brands' advertising elasticity is low, limiting the impact of competitive spending increases

35.brief: The LinkedIn B2B Institute, drawing on Ehrenberg-Bass research, highlights that at any given time approximately 95% of potential buyers are out-of-market, not actively looking to buy. Only about 5% are in-market at any moment. This has profound implications for B2B marketing: over 65% of B2B marketers believe that businesses grow by increasing loyalty, not customer acquisition, but the evidence contradicts this. This discrepancy presents B2B marketers with a precious, career-making opportunity: to be both right and contrarian. The Five Principles of Growth for B2B marketing include investing in share of voice, balancing brand and activation, maximizing reach, maximizing mental availability, and harnessing the power of emotion. Only 52% of B2B marketers believe reach is a strong predictor of advertising success. Those B2B marketers who are brave enough to reject consensus opinion and bet big on evidence-based principles will outperform their competition.
keyQuotes: Over 65% believe that businesses grow by increasing loyalty, not customer acquisition. This discrepancy presents B2B marketers with a precious, career-making opportunity: to be both right and contrarian. - LinkedIn B2B Institute

Only 52% believe reach is a strong predictor of advertising success. Those who are brave enough to reject consensus opinion and bet big on these principles will out-perform their competition. - LinkedIn B2B Institute
Advertising can generate further growth. Ads accelerate early growth and maintain higher sales over time. - LinkedIn B2B Report, Bass Diffusion Model
keyFindings: Approximately 95% of potential buyers are out-of-market at any given time
B2B marketing consensus is wrong: growth comes from acquisition, not loyalty
Being both right and contrarian about evidence-based marketing creates career-making opportunities
Reach, mental availability, and emotion are validated principles for B2B effectiveness

36.sources: Sharp (How Brands Grow), Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, Ephron
36.brief: The reach vs frequency debate centers on whether it's better to reach more people fewer times or fewer people more times. The evidence from Sharp and Ehrenberg-Bass favors maximizing reach. Advertising response follows diminishing marginal returns: each additional exposure produces less effect than the last, making the most cost-effective number of exposures one per person. It is best to use a continuous schedule that spreads the advertising across the target population as widely as possible. In this way, more people are reached, maximizing the return on advertising investment. Ephron advocated for weekly reach planning, which would mean being on air for more weeks at a lower weight. This shelf-space advertising model argues that advertising needs continuity because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. The implication is clear: broad reach with lower frequency is more efficient than narrow reach with high frequency, particularly for brand building.
keyQuotes: Each additional exposure produces less effect than the last. The most cost-effective number of exposures is one per person, and it is best to use a continuous schedule spread as widely as possible. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing

Advertising needs continuity, because not being there with a message is like being out-of-stock. Ephron advocated for weekly reach planning, being on air for more weeks at a lower weight. - Ephron, 1995
Brands grow primarily by increasing their market penetration, not by increasing loyalty among existing buyers. - Sharp, How Brands Grow
keyFindings: Diminishing returns make the optimal effective frequency one exposure per person
Continuous scheduling (more weeks at lower weight) outperforms flighting (fewer weeks at higher weight)
Broad reach maximizes the number of people who can be recruited to a brand
The shelf-space model treats advertising continuity as equivalent to retail availability

37.sources: Binet & Field (IPA Studies, The Long and the Short of It), Media in Focus
37.brief: Binet and Field document a growing marketing effectiveness crisis driven by short-termism. There is a growing tendency to use very short-term online metrics as primary performance measures. The major threat is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This threat will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management and its inevitable focus on short-term results. To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice, and there is an urgent need for long-term metrics to reassert their importance. The IPA Databank shows that if advertising effects decay in a non-exponential manner, it is almost impossible to predict the long-term sales effects of marketing activity from short-term responses. This raises serious questions about the reliability of short-term optimization. Media in Focus confirms that mass marketing still works, tight targeting has limitations, and the digital era requires new approaches to measuring effectiveness.
keyQuotes: To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice, and there is an urgent need for long-term metrics to reassert their importance. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
If advertising effects decay in a non-exponential manner, it is almost impossible to predict the long-term sales effects from short-term responses. - Binet & Field, The Long and the Short of It
The major threat is that the use of short-term metrics will damage the long-term profitability of brands. This will increase with the movement towards real-time campaign management. - Binet & Field
