keyFindings: Short-term metrics as primary KPIs actively damage long-term brand profitability
Real-time campaign management inevitably focuses on short-term results at the expense of brand building
Long-term advertising effects cannot be reliably predicted from short-term response data
The marketing industry is experiencing a systemic crisis of effectiveness driven by measurement myopia

38.sources: Binet & Field (Effectiveness in Context), IPA Databank analysis
38.brief: Attribution modeling faces fundamental challenges in accurately measuring marketing's contribution to business results. Binet and Field's work in Effectiveness in Context reveals that the migration from premium to value pricing is partly driven by brands focusing more on volume than pricing, a consequence of attribution models that favor measurable short-term activation over harder-to-measure brand building. If sales success is measured over a period of less than 6 months, the metric will favour short-term communications; if over longer than 6 months, it will favour long-term brand building. The implication is that most attribution models, which operate on short timeframes, systematically undervalue brand building. This creates a vicious cycle where budgets shift toward easily measurable activation, weakening brands over time. The consideration of brand versus activation must account for the systematic bias in how these effects are measured and attributed.
keyQuotes: If sales success is measured over less than 6 months, the metric will favour short-term tactics; if over longer than 6 months, it will favour long-term brand building. - Binet & Field
There is clear evidence of the migration from premium to value pricing as brands focus more on volume than pricing. - Binet & Field, Effectiveness in Context, p.112
It is almost impossible to predict the long-term sales effects of marketing activity from short-term responses. This raises serious questions. - Binet & Field
keyFindings: Most attribution models systematically undervalue brand building due to short measurement windows
Attribution bias toward measurable activation creates a vicious cycle of brand weakening
Brands have migrated from premium to value pricing partly due to attribution-driven budget allocation
Long-term effects cannot be predicted from short-term data, making most attribution fundamentally flawed

39.sources: Multiple Q3 sources: Binet & Field, Romaniuk, Ehrenberg-Bass, Lumen, GEO Research
39.brief: Q3 establishes the evidence base for marketing effectiveness and exposes the measurement crisis threatening it. Brand building ROI is real but only visible over 6+ month timeframes (Binet & Field). Mental availability metrics provide better tracking than traditional awareness measures (Romaniuk). Brands that go dark lose 10% market share per year (Phua et al.). GEO represents the next frontier of visibility optimization for AI-driven search. Share of Search provides a leading indicator of market share. Attention quality, not just viewability, determines advertising impact (Lumen). Double jeopardy confirms growth comes from penetration. Advertising elasticity shows diminishing returns favor reach over frequency. The 95-5 rule means 95% of potential buyers are out-of-market. And the marketing effectiveness crisis, driven by short-term metrics and flawed attribution, is systematically undervaluing brand building. The solution requires measuring what matters over the timeframes that matter.
keyQuotes: Losses were quantified as declining by 10% after one year, 20% after two years, and 28% after three years. - Phua et al., JAR 2023
GEO can improve visibility by up to 40%. SEO methods like keyword stuffing perform poorly in generative engines. - Aggarwal et al.
Marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice. - Binet & Field
keyFindings: The evidence overwhelmingly supports long-term brand building as the primary driver of growth
Current measurement practices systematically undervalue brand building and overvalue activation
New metrics (Share of Search, attention seconds, mental availability) better capture marketing effectiveness
AI-driven search (GEO) represents a fundamental shift in how brands maintain visibility

40.brief: Rory Sutherland's Alchemy argues that the opposite of a good idea can be a good idea. He introduces the concept of psycho-logic, which operates differently from conventional logic. Sutherland observes that in business, we've allowed the administrative cast to take over by dismissing trivial-seeming creative decisions. Yet in the success of a business, making it green can be more important than capacity planning. He describes the IKEA effect through Betty Crocker: psychologists believed that doing a little more work made women feel less guilty while still saving time, making just enough effort to give the sense of having contributed to the creation. Adding consumer effort increases someone's estimation of value. A 200 dress reduced to 75 is fine, but women may not feel happy wearing a 75 dress to a wedding. Economic logic is an attempt to create a psychology-free model of human behaviour based on presumptions of rationality, but it can be a very costly mistake. Not only can a rational approach to pricing be wrong, it can be catastrophically wrong.
keyQuotes: In the success of a business, making it green can be more important than talking about your capacity planning. What's happened in business is we've allowed the administrative cast to take over. - Sutherland, Alchemy
Economic logic is an attempt to create a psychology-free model of human behaviour based on presumptions of rationality, but it can be a very costly mistake. - Sutherland, Alchemy, p.229
There is a name for the addition of consumer effort to increase someone's estimation of value. It's known as the IKEA effect. - Sutherland, Alchemy, p.243
keyFindings: The opposite of a good idea can be a good idea, which rational models cannot accommodate
Psycho-logic operates differently from conventional logic and better explains consumer behavior
Adding consumer effort increases perceived value through the IKEA effect
Rational pricing models can be catastrophically wrong because they ignore psychological value

41.sources: Shotton (The Illusion of Choice), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing), Cialdini (Pre-Suasion)
41.brief: Shotton presents evidence that offering too much choice can cause decision-making to grind to a halt. Option overload can result in consumers choosing not to buy anything, or simply going for the default or cheapest option. This is a surprisingly effective way to make behaviour change easier: reduce the amount of choice you offer customers. Harhut notes that while choice can prompt decisions, too many choices (choice overload) can paralyze consumers. Cialdini connects this to the psychology of decision-making: for any decision maker, a painstaking comparative assessment of multiple options is difficult and stressful. Highly placed decision makers didn't get to their positions by being known as bottlenecks inside their organizations. Even in self-service settings, guidance in the form of labels and shelf talkers helps by directing consumer attention toward products suited to their needs. The wine shelves at the supermarket are a good example of a paralyzing array of choices. Wine shops deal with this profusion of options by offering categorized recommendations.
keyQuotes: Offering too much choice can cause decision-making to grind to a halt. Option overload can result in consumers choosing not to buy anything, or simply going for the default or cheapest option. - Shotton, The Illusion of Choice, p.38
While choice can prompt decisions, too many choices (choice overload) can paralyze consumers. - Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.121
For any decision maker, a painstaking comparative assessment of multiple options is difficult and stressful. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion, p.54
keyFindings: Too much choice causes decision paralysis, leading to no purchase or default selection
Reducing choice options can actually increase conversion and satisfaction
Guidance and categorization help consumers navigate large choice sets
Even experienced decision-makers find comparative assessment of many options stressful

42.brief: Robert Sapolsky's Behave explores the biological underpinnings of human behavior. Dopamine plays a crucial role: lots of dopamine is released when a signal comes on indicating the start of a reward trial, before the reward itself. The signal has gained the dopaminergic power of what is being signaled. This explains anticipation-based marketing. Rats will work to be exposed to a cue that signals that some kind of reward is likely, without knowing what or when. This is what fetishes are, in both the anthropological and sexual sense. The magnitude of an anticipatory dopamine rise reflects two variables: the size of the reward and the probability of receiving it. Adolescence is about risk taking and novelty seeking, driven by dopamine reward systems. We primates aren't driven out at adolescence. Instead we desperately crave novelty. The COMT gene variant affects dopamine signaling: a more efficient enzyme means less dopamine in the synapse, leading to different behavioral tendencies. Understanding these biological mechanisms reveals why anticipation, novelty, and reward prediction are fundamental to consumer behavior.
keyQuotes: Lots of dopamine is released when the signal comes on, signaling the start of a reward trial, before the reward itself. The signal has gained the dopaminergic power of what is being signaled. - Sapolsky, Behave, p.77

Rats will work to be exposed to a cue that signals that some kind of reward is likely, without knowing what or when. This is what fetishes are, in both the anthropological and sexual sense. - Sapolsky, Behave, p.78
We primates aren't driven out at adolescence. Instead we desperately crave novelty. Adolescence is about risk taking and novelty seeking. - Sapolsky, Behave, p.168
keyFindings: Dopamine is released during anticipation of reward, not just during reward receipt
The anticipation signal itself gains the dopaminergic power of the reward it predicts
Humans are biologically wired to crave novelty, explaining why new products and experiences attract attention
The magnitude of anticipatory dopamine reflects both reward size and probability

43.brief: MIT researchers examine the promises, perils, and future directions of labeling AI-generated content. Their research addresses three key challenges: identifying the correct subset of content to label, mitigating potential unintended consequences of labeling for broader media trust, and ensuring the efficacy and generalizability of labels across contexts. In their experiments, they tested six conditions: unlabeled control, 'AI-generated' label, 'Altered' label, 'Misleading' label, and combinations. Warning labels can reduce individuals' likelihood of believing and engaging with false and misleading information. However, important questions remain about how such labels might operate in the domain of AI-generated content. Hybrid strategies that blend machine learning, forensic techniques, and crowdsourcing may help improve the robustness of AI detection systems but are still vulnerable to the emergence of new forms of AI-generated content. These automated approaches require continual fine-tuning and adaptation to ensure they keep pace with advancements in AI technology.
keyQuotes: Warning labels can reduce individuals' likelihood of believing and engaging with false and misleading information, but important questions remain about how such labels might operate in the domain of AI-generated content. - Wittenberg et al., MIT 2024

Three key challenges: identifying the correct subset of content to label, mitigating unintended consequences of labeling for broader media trust, and ensuring efficacy across contexts. - Wittenberg et al., MIT 2024

Hybrid strategies that blend machine learning, forensic techniques, and crowdsourcing may help improve robustness but are still vulnerable to new forms of AI-generated content. - Wittenberg et al., MIT 2024
keyFindings: AI content labels can reduce belief in and engagement with misleading information
Labeling AI content risks unintended consequences for broader media trust
No single detection strategy is sufficient; hybrid approaches are needed but remain imperfect
Label effectiveness varies across contexts, requiring careful design and testing

44.sources: Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, IPA Effectiveness Awards
44.brief: The modern era of scientific advertising builds on a century of evidence about what makes advertising effective. Creativity is still required to produce ads that gain attention and engagement from the audience. By its nature, creativity cannot be anticipated. But after its creation, we can see features of an ad that help make it successful. Marketing scientists applied relevant methods under controlled scientific conditions so that they could gain full information on advertising effectiveness. The IPA Effectiveness Awards provide the most robust evidence base: 996 case studies, 700 brands, 83 categories over 30 years. The data shows that emotional campaigns consistently outperform rational ones for long-term brand building. Brand building effects accumulate over time while activation effects are temporary. The evidence challenges much of conventional marketing wisdom: growth comes from penetration not loyalty, mental availability drives brand choice, and the majority of consumers are out of market at any given time. Modern scientific advertising means applying behavioral science to creative development while measuring effects over appropriate timeframes.
keyQuotes: Creativity is still required to produce ads that gain attention and engagement from the audience. By its nature, creativity cannot be anticipated. But after its creation, we can see features that help make it successful. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.573

Marketing scientists applied relevant methods under controlled scientific conditions so that they could gain full information on advertising effectiveness. - Consumer Behaviour Applications in Marketing, p.601
996 case studies, 700 brands, 83 categories, 30 years. Effectiveness measured in terms of effects, not prizes. - Binet & Field, IPA
keyFindings: Modern scientific advertising is grounded in the largest effectiveness database ever assembled
Creativity cannot be prescribed in advance but successful features can be identified after creation
Emotional campaigns consistently outperform rational ones for long-term brand building
Evidence-based marketing challenges conventional wisdom about loyalty, targeting, and measurement

45.brief: Cialdini introduces the Unity principle as the seventh principle of influence in Pre-Suasion. Unity is about shared identity, the sense that 'we' are part of the same group. This goes beyond mere similarity (covered by the Liking principle) to encompass genuine tribal bonds. When people perceive a shared identity with a communicator, they are more receptive to persuasion because the communicator is seen as 'one of us.' Pre-Suasion shows that even subtle environmental cues can trigger shared identity: women perform better on math, science, and leadership tasks if assigned to rooms with cues (photos, for example) of women known to have mastered the tasks. The recommendation that ethical reputation should be part of assessments and that ratings by employees of a firm's ethical orientation should be a component of senior management's compensation shows how unity operates within organizations. True unity comes from shared experiences, shared values, and co-creation, not just demographic similarity.
keyQuotes: Women perform better on math, science, and leadership tasks if assigned to rooms with cues of women known to have mastered the tasks. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion

Ethical reputation of the company as a whole should be measured and included in assessments of yearly performance. Ratings by employees of the firm's ethical orientation should be a component of senior management's compensation. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion, p.226
A communicator pre-suades by focusing recipients initially on concepts that are aligned, associatively, with the information yet to be delivered. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion
keyFindings: Unity (shared identity) goes beyond similarity to encompass genuine tribal belonging
Environmental cues of shared identity improve performance and receptivity to messages
Shared identity makes communicators more persuasive because they are perceived as 'one of us'
Organizations can build unity through shared ethical values and co-creation experiences

46.brief: Pricing psychology reveals that consumers don't evaluate prices rationally. Dooley explains that precise pricing actually works: people are fooled by prices that are a penny cheaper despite conventional wisdom suggesting nobody is fooled. Removing dollar signs from prices dramatically improved willingness to purchase, with spending six percent more on average when the dollar sign was removed. How the price is graphically presented also matters. Sutherland notes that a 200 dress reduced to 75 is fine, but women may not feel happy wearing a 75 dress to a wedding. Economic logic as a psychology-free model based on presumptions of rationality can be a very costly mistake. Barden's Decoded approach suggests starting with the best option and getting customers to subtract down, rather than building from a base. In a 2022 study of 404 shoppers, Haagen-Dazs looked 52% better value when compared to a costlier Halo Top ($4.99) versus a cheaper Walmart tub ($1.99). The value judgment didn't change due to the product itself, but the comparison context.
keyQuotes: Removing a dollar sign from your price dramatically improved the likeliness to purchase, spending six percent more on average. - Brainfluence, citing Sybil Yang, San Francisco University

A 200 dress reduced to 75 is fine, but women may not feel happy wearing a 75 dress to a wedding. Economic logic based on presumptions of rationality can be a very costly mistake. - Sutherland, Alchemy, p.229

Haagen-Dazs looked 52% better value when compared to a costlier $4.99 Halo Top versus a cheaper $1.99 Walmart tub. The value judgment changed based on the comparison context. - Nudge-Vault, 2022 study
keyFindings: Removing currency symbols increases willingness to pay by approximately 6%
Price perception is heavily influenced by the reference context, not absolute value
Precise prices (e.g., $3.99 not $4.00) are more effective than round numbers despite seeming trivial
Psychological value and economic value are fundamentally different concepts in pricing

47.brief: Cialdini identifies liking as a powerful principle of influence. Joe Girard, the world's greatest car salesman, attributed his success to just two things: a fair price and someone the customer liked to buy from. Physical attractiveness is one factor: studies show that attractive people are more likely to receive favorable treatment. But similarity is perhaps more powerful: we like people who are like us. It's a fact that applies to human infants as well as adults. Compliance practitioners leverage similarity by mirroring the target's opinions, traits, and behaviors. Compliments also generate liking, even when the recipient suspects ulterior motives. As Mae West observed, 'Flattery will get you everywhere.' Waitresses who compliment diners' choices get larger tips. The key defense against the liking principle is to be alert to a sense of undue liking for a compliance practitioner and to separate the requester from the request. Once immersed in even brief personal contact with a requester, we may easily forget that distinction.
keyQuotes: Joe Girard attributed his success to two things: a fair price and someone they liked to buy from. Put them both together, and you get a deal. - Cialdini, Influence
We like people who are like us. It's a fact that applies to human infants as well as adults. - Cialdini, Influence, p.86

Be alert to a sense of undue liking for a compliance practitioner. Once immersed in even brief personal contact with a requester, we may easily forget the distinction between the requester and the request. - Cialdini, Influence
keyFindings: Liking is driven by physical attractiveness, similarity, compliments, contact, and cooperation
Similarity is a particularly powerful driver: we like people who are like us across all ages
Compliments generate liking even when the recipient suspects ulterior motives
The key vulnerability is failing to separate our feelings about the requester from the request itself

48.brief: Cognitive load theory explains how mental effort constraints affect decision-making. Kahneman describes how when a critical stimulus was presented at a time of high demand, subjects simply did not see it. When the task was less demanding, detection performance was better. This demonstrates the sophisticated allocation of attention: the brain cannot process everything simultaneously. Cialdini connects this to persuasion: in addition to its time-challenged character, modern life undermines our ability and motivation to think thoroughly. We're not able to focus on the real quality of an advertiser's case in a radio or television spot. Nor are we able to respond mindfully to a news clip. Instead, we're left to focus on secondary features of the presentations, such as the attractiveness of the spokesperson or the politician's charisma. Mental multiplication of two-digit numbers and similar tasks are near the limit of what most people can do, and the request to retrieve information while organizing a response requires significant effort. Understanding cognitive load helps marketers design communications that work within cognitive constraints rather than fighting against them.
keyQuotes: When a critical stimulus was presented at a time of high demand, subjects simply did not see it. When the task was less demanding, detection performance was better. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.37

We're not able to focus on the real quality of an advertiser's case in a radio or television spot. Instead, we're left to focus on secondary features such as the attractiveness of the spokesperson. - Cialdini, Pre-Suasion, p.154

Mental multiplication of two-digit numbers are near the limit of what most people can do. The request to retrieve and say aloud your phone number requires a brief but significant effort. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.38
keyFindings: Under high cognitive load, people literally cannot see or process additional information
Modern life systematically undermines the ability to think deeply about marketing messages
When cognitive capacity is constrained, people rely on peripheral cues (attractiveness, charisma)
Effective marketing must work within cognitive constraints rather than demanding deep processing

49.sources: Kahneman & Tversky (Judgment Under Uncertainty, Thinking, Fast and Slow)
49.brief: The availability heuristic is employed when people are asked to assess the frequency of a class or the likelihood of an event. A person is said to employ the availability heuristic when they assess frequency by the ease with which instances come to mind. Kahneman and Tversky established three key heuristics for judgment under uncertainty: representativeness, availability of instances or scenarios, and anchoring. The availability heuristic means that events that are more memorable or vivid are judged as more frequent, regardless of actual statistical frequency. This creates systematic biases: dramatic events (plane crashes) are judged as more common than mundane ones (car accidents) because they are more memorable. The heuristic extends to social perception: erroneous perceptions with severe consequences may persist because there is a bias in the formation of a judgment that leads to a bias in maintaining that judgment via the cognitive structure formed. These complementary biases can be highly resistant to correction.
keyQuotes: A person is said to employ the availability heuristic when they assess frequency by the ease with which instances come to mind. - Kahneman & Tversky, Judgment Under Uncertainty, p.189
Three heuristics for judgment under uncertainty: representativeness, availability of instances or scenarios, and anchoring. - Kahneman & Tversky, Thinking, Fast and Slow, p.429

Erroneous perceptions may persist because there is a bias in formation that leads to a bias in maintaining that judgment. These complementary biases can be highly resistant to correction. - Judgment Under Uncertainty, p.198
keyFindings: People judge frequency and likelihood by how easily examples come to mind, not actual statistics
Vivid, emotional, and recent events are disproportionately available in memory
Availability bias creates self-reinforcing cycles where initial judgments are maintained
Marketing that creates memorable, vivid associations will make brands seem more prevalent

50.sources: Thaler & Sunstein (Nudge), Harhut (Using Behavioral Science in Marketing), Kahneman
50.brief: Status quo bias means people have a strong preference for the current state of affairs. Thaler and Sunstein explain that status quo bias is easily exploited, using the example of magazine subscriptions that auto-renew. Unless action is taken to cancel, the subscription continues indefinitely. In Harhut's research, subjects told to imagine they had inherited money and given four investment portfolios to choose from showed strong status quo bias: when one portfolio was described as the one currently holding the money, it was disproportionately chosen. The endowment effect is related: in experiments, half the students received coffee mugs and half got chocolate bars. When offered the opportunity to switch, only one in ten did. Your customers will have a strong preference for the status quo, for the way things are. It might be due to familiarity, loss aversion, time and effort already invested, or habit. Marketers should have inertia work in their favor by making 'doing nothing' actually result in the behavior they seek.
keyQuotes: Status quo bias is easily exploited. Unless he took some action to cancel his subscription, he would automatically keep receiving the magazines. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.42
When offered the opportunity to switch from a mug to a candy bar or vice versa, only one in ten switched. - Thaler & Sunstein, Nudge, p.41
Have inertia work in your favor. Make 'doing nothing' actually result in the behavior you seek. Precheck desired options. - Harhut, Using Behavioral Science in Marketing, p.179
keyFindings: People disproportionately choose the status quo even when objectively better options exist
Status quo bias is driven by familiarity, loss aversion, sunk costs, and habit
Only 10% of people will switch equivalent items they already possess, demonstrating endowment effects
Marketers can leverage status quo bias by making desired behaviors the default

51.sources: Norton & Ariely (via Nudge Podcast, The Illusion of Choice), Sutherland (Alchemy)
51.brief: The IKEA effect, identified by researchers Michael Norton and Dan Ariely, demonstrates that when you build IKEA furniture yourself you prefer it to pre-built furniture. If you see the labor that's gone into a task, you'll value it more. Sutherland traces this to Betty Crocker: when instant cake mixes required only adding water, sales were poor. When the recipe was changed to require adding an egg, sales increased. The psychologists believed that doing a little more work made consumers feel less guilty while still saving time, but making just enough effort to give the sense of having contributed. The IKEA effect requires task completion: participants who fully built a box valued it more, but the effect disappears if the task is not completed. Shotton describes the related labour illusion: when participants were shown a suitable date, being transparent about the effort made users even happier. But when shown an unsuitable date, transparency about effort made them even unhappier. It seems this effect exaggerates people's opinions of brands rather than overturns them. In a study of children ages 3-6, five and six year olds rated toy monsters they helped build more highly, suggesting the effect emerges with identity development.
keyQuotes: The IKEA effect, identified by Norton and Ariely: when you build IKEA furniture yourself you prefer it to pre-built furniture. If you see the labor that's gone into a task, you'll value it more. - Nudge Podcast
The addition of consumer effort to increase someone's estimation of value should perhaps be called the Betty Crocker effect, but it's known as the IKEA effect. - Sutherland, Alchemy, p.243
The IKEA effect requires task completion. Participants who fully built a box valued it more, but the effect disappears if the task is not completed. - Nudge-Vault, p.19
keyFindings: Personal effort in creating something increases its perceived value disproportionately
The IKEA effect requires task completion: incomplete tasks don't generate the value boost
The labour illusion exaggerates existing opinions rather than overturning them
The effect emerges in children around age 5-6 as identity develops, suggesting it is tied to self-concept

52.topic: Annual Synthesis: The Behavioral Marketing Framework
52.sources: All 52 weeks: Sharp, Kahneman, Cialdini, Binet & Field, Romaniuk, Sutherland, Shotton, Sapolsky, Google Research, Ehrenberg-Bass Institute
52.brief: The complete behavioral marketing framework integrates 52 weeks of evidence-based insights into a coherent system. At the foundation level, System 1 processing dominates consumer decisions (Kahneman), mental availability determines which brands get chosen (Sharp, Romaniuk), and dopamine-driven anticipation and novelty-seeking shape attention (Sapolsky). At the influence level, Cialdini's seven principles (reciprocity, commitment, social proof, authority, liking, scarcity, unity) provide systematic levers for persuasion. At the market level, the 60:40 rule (Binet & Field), SOV/SOM relationship, double jeopardy law, and 95-5 rule establish the evidence base for marketing investment. At the measurement level, the effectiveness crisis demands new metrics including Share of Search, attention seconds, and mental availability tracking. At the creative level, emotional right-brain advertising (Wood) outperforms rational left-brain approaches, while psycho-logic (Sutherland) shows that the opposite of a good idea can be a good idea. Together, this framework provides a complete evidence-based system for marketing that challenges conventional wisdom at every turn.
keyQuotes: System 1 is the secret author of many of the choices and judgments you make. - Kahneman, Thinking, Fast and Slow
To an alarming degree, marketing appears to be sleepwalking towards a precipice. - Binet & Field
The opposite of a good idea can be a good idea. Economic logic based on presumptions of rationality can be a very costly mistake. - Sutherland, Alchemy
keyFindings: Consumer decisions are dominated by System 1 automatic processing, not rational deliberation
Brand growth comes from mental availability and penetration, not differentiation and loyalty
Long-term emotional brand building outperforms short-term rational activation
The marketing industry faces a measurement crisis that systematically undervalues what actually works
